description: From Middle English pursyf (“short of breath, asthmatic”), probably from Old French pousser (“to push; to breathe with difficulty”); see French poussif (“wheezy”).

entries.meaning: Out of breath; short of breath, especially due to fatness.
examples: We now set off in pursuit of her, all but the farmer, who, being pretty fat and pursy, was not for running a race  […]
[…]  the vicar  […]  was particularly fond of boys in general. Not so the doctor, a pursy little man with a terrific frown, who hated boys, especially little ones, with a very powerful hatred.

description: From purse (“pucker”) +‎ -y and purse (“small bag for carrying money”) +‎ -y.

examples: So Aunt Bell sat down to table—a bony frame, with an anxious green eye, a pursy mouth, and a sweating sickness of bitter words, seeking to break forth at the earliest opportunity.
